Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowships in Biology combine research and training to prepare young scientists for careers in emerging areas where biology intersects with other scientific disciplines, in this case with mathematics and economics. The Fellows are expected to be leaders of the nation's scientific workforce of the future. This fellowship to Zak Ratajczak supports research and training that address the question, "Does economic connectedness undermine environmental stability?" The host institutions for this fellowship are the University of Virginia and Stockholm University and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Paolo D'Odorico and Carl Folke, respectively. Training goals for the fellowship include developing skills in theoretical modeling of modern social-ecological systems, including nonlinear dynamics and network theory. The research results are expected to be useful to public policy and are being disseminated through workshops with multiple stakeholder groups and policy recommendations. Educational outreach to K-12 and undergraduate groups seeks to foster deeper thinking of how humans and ecosystems affect each other. This fellowship is jointly funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering, the Directorate for Geosciences, and the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

This research addresses the extent to which ecological and social-ecological systems are capable of abrupt and difficult-to-reverse transitions, referred to as 'tipping points.' The research represents ecosystems as a series of ecological components interconnected over long distances by human economies an advance over many models that consider only naturally occurring connections between ecosystems. It addresses whether these economic connections accentuate existing tipping points and create large-scale ecological tipping points that do not exist in the absence of humans. Using these models, the research seeks to identify adaptive strategies to avoid tipping points, including alterations of underlying biological diversity. Analyses of different modes of market behavior and resource sharing should provide strategies for navigating stochastic fluctuations in natural resources. Furthermore, by explicitly integrating conspicuous components of ecosystem structure and the price indexes of key biological goods into the models, it should be possible to detect dynamic behaviors that often emerge near tipping points in social-ecological networks. Being aware of such behaviors could help avoid large ecological tipping in economically important ecosystems such as croplands, rangelands, and fisheries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Critical transitions are difficult to reverse transitions in ecological and social-ecological systems, which occur when a system crosses a threshold or “tipping point”. This grant has explored how biological and human changes in driver variables and connectivity alter the rate and extent of critical transitions. We also worked on tools for forecasting critical transitions.

 

Ecological systems are especially susceptible to critical transitions during pulses, which are acute but temporary changes in driver variables. Using simulations, we have found that as the intensity of pulse increases, the length of time a system can withstand a pulse and still recover shrinks rapidly. This property is consistent across diverse model systems, include lakes, grazing lands, consumer populations, and rainforests. At these times, humans will have to alter driver variables to avoid critical transitions. Moreover, spatial properties, such as low connectivity and high heterogeneity, can creates the potential for “second chances” during pulses, because critical transitions are less likely to spread throughout the whole system. This grant has also supported work on real-world systems, including socially important grasslands and food production systems. For instance, this grant contributed to a set of studies quantifying country-scale susceptibility to food supply shocks due to disruptions of food-trade and losses of local food production. We also used long-term experiments to assess how long ecosystems can withstand pulses without undergoing critical transitions.

 

Our work on connectivity has looked at the properties of networks. In our early work, we explored how simple three-component networks can avoid critical transitions by balancing different negative interactions between components. Scaling up to larger systems, we have used simulations to explore how habitat destruction can result in critical transitions in systems with short-range connections or large-scale feedback mechanisms. These simulations suggest that human alterations of connectivity can force critical transitions in important ecosystems, including rainforests. In another set of simulations, we have explored the properties of artificial social-ecological systems, where natural resources pools are connected to human consumer markets through trade markets. These trade networks are adaptive, with human consumer markets exerting demand on resource pools and repartitioning that demand if resource pools undergo critical transitions. This model lets us test whether the connectivity and modularity of trade networks alters the amount of human demand that can be sustained and the extent of critical transitions (collapses) of resource pools. In this framework, connectivity refers to the proportion of markets and resource pools that are connected by trade and modularity refers to whether markets tend to form tight-knit groups. Our simulations suggest that low connectivity networks are poor at meeting large amounts of human demand, but less prone to large-scale critical transitions across resource pools. High connectivity networks excel at meeting greater levels of demand, but only up to a point. Once a threshold in demand is exceeded, the high connectivity trade networks undergo critical transitions that cascade across resource pools. Intermediate connectivity networks, surprisingly, were least effective at meeting demand and avoiding critical transitions. Modularity can also increase the amount of human demand that systems can withstand before large-scale critical transitions occur, but only at very high levels of modularity.

 

Another key goal of this grant was to develop tools that allow humans to recognize and forecast critical transitions. Our work has used simulations and long-term experiments to show that—from a human standpoint—many critical transitions actually occur slowly, taking several years to several decades to unfold. These slow critical transitions can be difficult to distinguish from more innocuous forms of ecological change over time. We found that due to this slow rate of change, some of the early warning signs thought to signal an approaching threshold can also occur when a system is in the middle of a critical transition. This result highlights the difficulty of determining when a system is approaching a threshold or undergoing a slow critical transition.

 

The broader impacts of this grant have focused heavily on graduate student training. Over the course of this grant, the PI has mentored five students on their thesis/dissertation work, three of whom were international students. The PI also contributed to three projects lead by post-doctoral researchers. Direct outreach occurred through presentations at meetings attended by multiple stakeholders and helping organize workshops that consisted of an equal mix of scientists and land-managers. This grant has supported the development of teaching tools, such as publically available and easy-to-use computer code for students to perform simulations. Developing these resources was part of training an early career scientist (the PI), who is now equipped to teach modeling and computer simulation to students.
